brand_context.site_description: Mailchimp is an all-in-one marketing platform that helps small businesses market smarter so they can grow faster. We offer email marketing, automation, websites, social media tools, CRM capabilities, and audience insights. Founded as a small business ourselves, we understand the challenges entrepreneurs face and build tools that make professional marketing accessible to everyone.
brand_context.audience: Small business owners, entrepreneurs, solo marketers, and creators who want to grow their business through digital marketing. Many are running their business alongside other responsibilities and need tools that are powerful yet approachable.

voice_tone.description: Human, familiar, and straightforward. We're the experienced and compassionate business partner we wish we'd had. We use dry humor—straight-faced, subtle, and a touch eccentric. We prioritize clarity over entertainment.
voice_tone.tone_notes: Our tone is generally informal, but it's always more important to be clear than entertaining. Adjust tone based on the reader's emotional state—be more serious in error messages, more playful in success states. Our mascot Freddie smiles and winks, but he does not talk—never write in his voice.

dos: Use active voice: Marti logged in instead of The account was logged into
Write in plain English that anyone can understand
Use positive language over negative
Lead with the main point and most important information
Use contractions freely to sound friendly and approachable
Use the serial comma
Write short sentences that are easy to scan
Put yourself in the reader's shoes before writing
Simplify complex terminology
Use gender-neutral language and singular they
Break up long passages with subheadings
Front-load paragraphs with key information
donts: Do not use passive voice constructions
Avoid slang and unexplained jargon
Never patronize or talk down to readers
Do not use clickbait or sensational language
Avoid vague language and unnecessary modifiers
Never force jokes that feel unnatural
Do not use directional language like click the button on the left
Avoid double negatives
Do not use blacklist or whitelist—use blocklist and allowlist
Never assume technical knowledge
Avoid starting sentences with There is or There are

prefer.note: Always capitalize the M and lowercase c
Preferred over blast or newsletter blast
Preferred over list or subscriber list
One word as adjective or noun

avoid.note: Sounds impersonal and aggressive—use email campaign
Corporate buzzword—be specific about what you mean
Use simpler words like use or take advantage of
What's simple to you may not be to others
Minimizing word that implies tasks are trivial
Condescending—if it were obvious, you would not need to say it

voice_corrections: click here to descriptive link text

These references represent our gold standard for content. When in doubt, refer to the public style guide.

images.style: Authentic, warm, and diverse. Show real small business scenarios with natural lighting. Feature people who look like our actual customers—diverse in age, ethnicity, ability, and style. Avoid generic corporate imagery.
images.alt_text_guidelines: Describe both the content and purpose of the image. For decorative images, use empty alt text. Keep alt text under 125 characters. Never start with image of or picture of.
dos: Use authentic imagery that reflects our diverse customer base
Show real small business scenarios and environments
Include clear, readable screenshots with annotations when helpful
Use natural lighting that feels warm and approachable
Feature real products and workspaces over stock photos
Include alt text for all informative images
donts: Avoid generic stock photos with forced smiles
Do not use low-resolution or pixelated images
Never include sensitive customer data in screenshots
Avoid overly polished or corporate-looking imagery
Do not use images that require cultural context to understand
Never use images with embedded text as the only way to convey information

guidelines.notes:
Mailchimp began as a small business ourselves. We know marketing technology can be a minefield of confusing terminology. That is why we speak like the experienced and compassionate business partner we wish we had.

We prioritize clarity over entertainment. When humor works naturally, use it. When it does not, skip it.

Remember that our audience spans the globe. Write for translation: use simple sentence structures, avoid idioms and cultural references that may not translate well.

Always consider the reader's emotional state. Someone troubleshooting an error needs clear, direct help—not jokes. Someone celebrating a successful campaign can enjoy a lighter touch.

dos: Keep paragraphs to 3-4 sentences maximum
Lead with the main point
Use plain language that anyone can understand
Break up long content with subheadings
Use transition words sparingly
donts: Do not start paragraphs with However or Additionally
Avoid walls of text
Never bury important information mid-paragraph
Do not use complex sentence structures

core/paragraph.notes: Write for scanning—most readers skim first. If a paragraph exceeds 4 sentences, consider breaking it up or using a list.

dos: Use sentence case for H2 and below
Make headings descriptive of content that follows
Follow heading hierarchy strictly (H1 → H2 → H3)
Keep headings under 8 words when possible
Use headings to create scannable structure
donts: Do not use questions as headings unless rhetorical
Avoid single-word headings
Never skip heading levels (H2 → H4)
Do not use headings for styling purposes
Avoid headings that all sound the same

core/heading.notes: Headings are navigation aids. Someone should understand the article structure from headings alone. Page titles (H1) use title case; all other headings use sentence case.

dos: Use action verbs that describe what happens next
Keep button text under 5 words
Use sentence case
Make button purpose clear out of context
Start with a verb when possible
donts: Do not use Click here or Learn more alone
Avoid generic Submit or Send
Never use all caps
Do not use punctuation in button text
Avoid vague actions like Go or Continue

core/button.notes: Think of buttons as completing: I want to... Good examples: Create campaign, Download report, Start free trial. Buttons should make sense without surrounding context.

dos: Use parallel structure for all list items
Keep items concise and scannable
Order logically—by importance, sequence, or alphabetically
Introduce lists with a lead-in sentence
Use numbered lists for sequential steps
donts: Do not mix sentence fragments with full sentences
Avoid lists with only 2 items—use a sentence instead
Never use a list when a simple sentence would work
Do not end list items with semicolons
Avoid deeply nested lists (more than 2 levels)

core/list.notes: Lists are powerful for scannability. Use bulleted lists for non-sequential items, numbered lists for steps or ranked items.

dos: Write descriptive alt text that conveys image purpose
Include captions that add context beyond the image
Keep alt text under 125 characters
Describe the function, not just appearance
donts: Do not leave alt text empty for informative images
Avoid starting alt text with Image of or Picture of
Never use images of text as the only way to convey information
Do not include redundant information in captions

core/image.notes: Alt text should describe what a screen reader user needs to know. For decorative images, use empty alt text. For complex images like charts, provide a text summary.

dos: Include attribution for all quotes
Use quotes to add authority or human perspective
Keep quotes relevant to surrounding content
Verify quote accuracy
donts: Do not use quotes for visual emphasis
Avoid very long quotes—summarize when possible
Never alter quotes without indicating changes
Do not use pull quotes that repeat nearby text

core/quote.notes: Quotes work best when they add a human voice or expert credibility. Always include who said it and their relevant context.

dos: Use inline code for short references like variable names
Use code blocks for multi-line examples
Include comments for complex code
Test code examples before publishing
donts: Do not use code formatting for emphasis
Avoid unexplained code snippets
Never include sensitive information like API keys
Do not assume readers know programming concepts

core/code.notes: Code examples should be copy-paste ready and tested. Always explain what the code does in plain language before or after the block.

dos: Use clear, concise header labels
Align numbers to the right for easy comparison
Include a caption describing the table
Keep tables simple—consider breaking up complex data
donts: Do not use tables for layout purposes
Avoid tables with too many columns (more than 5-6)
Never leave cells empty without explanation
Do not merge cells unless absolutely necessary

core/table.notes: Tables are great for comparing data. Include a header row and consider mobile users—complex tables may need alternative presentations.

dos: Use separators to indicate major topic shifts
Use consistently throughout a piece
donts: Do not overuse separators
Avoid using separators between every section
Never use separators as visual decoration

core/separator.notes: Separators indicate a significant break in content. If sections are related, use headings instead.

dos: Keep content length balanced across columns
Use columns for comparing related information
Consider mobile stacking behavior
donts: Do not use columns for unrelated content
Avoid more than 3 columns on standard content
Never put long-form content in narrow columns

core/columns.notes: Columns work best for side-by-side comparisons or feature highlights. Remember that columns stack on mobile.

dos: Use groups to create visual sections
Maintain consistent spacing within groups
donts: Do not nest groups too deeply
Avoid using groups purely for background colors

core/group.notes: Groups help organize related content visually. Use them to create clear content sections.

dos: Balance text length with image size
Use for feature highlights or introductions
Ensure text and image complement each other
donts: Do not use for long-form content
Avoid small images with lots of text
Never use decorative images that do not support the text

core/media-text.notes: Media-text blocks work well for product features, testimonials, or section introductions. Keep text concise.

dos: Keep overlay text short and impactful
Ensure sufficient contrast for readability
Use for section headers or calls to action
donts: Do not use cover blocks for body content
Avoid busy background images that compete with text
Never rely solely on color contrast—consider all users

core/cover.notes: Cover blocks create visual impact. Test readability across different screens and ensure text remains visible.

dos: Include alt text for each image
Use captions to add context
Curate galleries—quality over quantity
donts: Do not include duplicate or very similar images
Avoid galleries with only 1-2 images
Never mix unrelated images in a single gallery

core/gallery.notes: Galleries showcase multiple related images. Each image should serve a purpose and have descriptive alt text.

dos: Provide context before embedded content
Consider users who cannot access embedded content
Use embeds to add value, not fill space
donts: Do not embed auto-playing media
Avoid embeds that slow page loading significantly
Never embed content without reviewing it first

core/embed.notes: Embeds bring in external content. Always introduce what the embed contains and why it is relevant.

dos: Include captions or transcripts for accessibility
Provide context about video content and length
Use descriptive titles
donts: Do not autoplay videos
Avoid very long videos without chapter markers
Never use video when text would be more efficient

core/video.notes: Videos should be accessible with captions. Let users know what to expect before they click play.

dos: Provide transcripts for accessibility
Include duration and content description
Use descriptive file names and titles
donts: Do not autoplay audio
Avoid audio-only content without text alternative
Never use audio for critical information without backup

core/audio.notes: Audio content needs text alternatives. Always include transcripts and let users control playback.

dos: Use descriptive file names
Include file size and format
Explain what the file contains
donts: Do not use generic names like Document.pdf
Avoid very large files without warning
Never upload files containing sensitive information

core/file.notes: File blocks should clearly communicate what users are downloading and why it is valuable.

dos: Use for key insights worth highlighting
Keep pullquotes concise
Include attribution when quoting someone
donts: Do not repeat text verbatim from nearby paragraphs
Avoid overusing pullquotes—one per section maximum
Never use pullquotes just for visual interest

core/pullquote.notes: Pullquotes highlight key points. They should offer value to readers who are scanning.

dos: Use clear, descriptive summary text
Keep collapsed content focused
Use for supplementary information
donts: Do not hide critical information in collapsed sections
Avoid nesting details within details
Never use for primary content users must see

core/details.notes: Details blocks help manage information density. The summary should clearly indicate what is inside.

dos: Use for citations and supplementary notes
Keep footnote content concise
Number footnotes consistently
donts: Do not use footnotes for essential information
Avoid very long footnotes
Never use footnotes in place of inline explanations

core/footnotes.notes: Footnotes are for references and tangential information. Important content belongs in the main text.
